intro: Acacia congesta subsp. congesta, commonly known as the coastal wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to southern Australia. It is characterized by its compound leaves, which are often covered in fine, soft hairs. The plant produces yellow flowers in dense, globular clusters, typically during the autumn and winter months. It thrives in coastal areas and sandy soils, showing some tolerance to salt spray. This subspecies is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it a resilient component of coastal vegetation.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive foliage and often symbiotic relationships with nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Its species is Acacia congesta, a particular subspecies known for its dense foliage and ecological importance in arid environments.

This subspecies thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often associated with coastal and inland areas. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range. The plant is an important component of the local flora and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils.

It has been widely planted for its ornamental value and its ability to thrive in coastal and Mediterranean climates. The plant is commonly found in gardens and along roadsides due to its hardy nature and attractive foliage. It has also been introduced to other parts of southern Africa, including Namibia and southern Botswana. However, its spread outside of cultivated areas is limited compared to other acacia species.
